awd_titl_txt: REU Site: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley REU Program on Applied Mathematics and Computational and Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley, will host eight students over the course of nine weeks to work collaboratively on group research projects in applied mathematics, mathematical modeling and computational and data science, applying theoretical models to physical and biological phenomena. Students will acquire a wide range of computational skills by receiving training on numerical methods and their coding. The program will provide students with invaluable educational and research skills and experiences and better prepare them for graduate programs and careers in STEM. One of the goals is to diversify the STEM fields, with plans for more than 50% of participants coming from under-represented minorities and under-represented groups in STEM. The program will also provide mentoring to early-career faculty, allowing them to grow professionally as effective mentors for undergraduate research themselves. Students will disseminate research results by presenting at mathematics and interdisciplinary conferences, publishing papers in journals, and by coding computer software, which will be made freely available.  

This REU program will provide undergraduate students with vigorous, motivating, and above all quality collaborative research experience in the areas of stochastic and deterministic partial differential equations and numerical analysis with an emphasis on the computational aspects. Additionally, students will develop and/or apply deep spatial learning algorithms to spatial processes resulting from partial differential equations. As a first objective, students will study and analyze novel and engaging topics such as the dynamics of scattering waves and propagation of nonlinear waves in non-uniform media. As a second objective, students will work on simulating spatial processes such as the spread of diseases or emission of pollution, which are modeled using partial differential equations with space-time white or color noise. Students will also produce predictive models and compare their outcomes to actual models of spatial processes. Understanding how to address each model computationally will have a broad impact on the students’ ability to tackle other mathematical models and be competitive as applicants to graduate programs as well as in industry. Moreover, students will be enriched academically with workshops in scientific writing, presentation skills, and graduate school readiness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our successful program at UTRGV ran during Summers 2022, 2023, and 2024, impacting 24 undergraduate participants.Please see our WEbpage for more details https://www.utrgv.edu/smss-nsf-reu/index.htm.

 We successfully met all of our objectives: 1. To give students a fundamental background of modeling real life problems by the use differential equations; 2. To provide practice in applying mathematical modeling using computer mathematical programs such as MATLAB and Python; 3. To provide students with experience working in a group to solve a real research problem in with faculty with great potential to be published; 4. Introduce students to data science and explore possibilities of using these tools to create solutions for differential equations; 5. To write the results from faculty and students in a publishable paper; and 6. To increase the students’ interest in graduate programs and careers in mathematics.

Our recruitment was robust, reaching students from across the country, many from primarily undergraduate-serving institutions, including UTRGV.  

Intellectual Merit. Students received extensive training in MATLAB and Python  and how to use it to do stochastic and Monte Carlo simulations. They used MATLAB and Python to find numerical solutions of differential and partial differential equations. Students were trained on MATLAB and Python toolboxes like the deep learning toolbox, which they used to make artificial neural networks to simulate SIR models and the Lorenz equation to model chaos. Students used these neural networks to solve fractional differential equations. They also utilized the deep learning toolbox in MATLAB and Python to do convolutional neural networks, using them for the classification of solutions of integer partial differential equations against fractional partial differential equations. Students were introduced to one of the popular machine learning techniques, artificial neural network (ANN), its working mechanism, and the associated deep learning concepts associated. Students applied this knowledge to real-life problems introduced by mentor faculty, resulting in four published academic journal articles, three of which are Q1: “Oscillations in neuronal activity: A neuron-centered spatiotemporal model of the unfolded protein,” “Monte Carlo simulations for fractional differential equations of higher order and a Wright-type transformation,” “Exact solutions of stochastic Burgers-KdV equations with variable coefficients” and “Using Convolutional neural networks to predict the order of fractional partial differential equations”.

Further, students were given real-life practice as they disseminated their results. Each summer the PI organized the NSF REU seminar in which student teams presented their research in front of the faculty and students at UTRGV in a weekly basis. During Fall 2022, the PI organized an international conference titled “INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR OF MATHEMATICS: JUUNTOS UTRGV-UNAL” where all 8 participants from Summer 2022 presented their work. The following years once pandemic was over students have also presented at regional conferences: the Texas Undergraduate Mathematics Conference (2024), the Texas Undergraduate Mathematics Conference (2024), New Connections in Math (2024), the Nebraska Conference for Undergraduate Women in Mathematics (2024), SIAM Texas & Louisiana Conference (2024), Texas STEM conference at Lamar University (2023); the Joint Mathematics Meeting (2023 and 2024); the Gulf Coast Conference (2023); as well as at their home universities.

Broader Impacts. We are confident that our REU activities made important contributions to the lives of our participants and to the broader human trajectory of the field. Students participated actively each Friday in a mentor-led professional development series. Topics covered included: General and Math Subject GRE workshops; practice GRE sessions; how to give a talk/poster; graduate application workshop; applying for conference travel support; careers in STEM Panel;  CV and personal statement writing assignments; and thriving in a graduate program workshop. Students were engaged throughout the series because they could see immediate applications.  

Student comments in our post-REU survey were uniformly positive, with statements like “Before coming to the REU, I didn’t really know what type of mathematician I would be. Mostly because I have never had the experience to doable (sic) in research. I see now that there are many more fields of mathematics;” “Participating in the REU has developed a strong bond with math. It has shown me how much more complex the subject is and has made me want to pursue a graduate degree;” and “It has really opened my eyes to the possibilities with math research on the future, whether it be a masters or PhD program.” We are proud to have made such an impact on these individual students’ STEM and professional development.

We are already beginning to see the most important results of the REU – student success in graduate programs:  Three are pursuing a master’s degree; five are already pursuing PhDs, and all other students are finishing their bachelor’s degrees, some participating in other REUs with recommendations from the PIs.  We are proud of the potential impact our REU will have in the future of STEM fields.
